entry.title: Jekyll tips
entry.content:
Some tips- in no particular order

Tip #1

It's perfectly valid to mix .markdown files and .html files in your _posts folder.
entry.summary: Some tips- in no particular order Tip #1 It's perfectly valid to mix .markdown files and .html files in your _posts folder.

entry.title: Gotchyas presented by jekyll
entry.content:
Gotchya #1

 Out of the box, the rendering engine (is it liquid?) will not render pages that are date stamped at a future time.  Spent 20 minutes trying to figure out why my page wasnt generating.  =(

Gotchya #2

The date prepended in the post file name (yyyy-mm-dd-you-post-name) does not matter at all.  In fact, the title also does not matter.  The values in the "front matter" portion of the posts is what is used to determine if a post will be generated for the site.
entry.summary: Gotchya #1  Out of the box, the rendering engine (is it liquid?) will not render pages that are date stamped at a future time.  Spent 20 minutes trying to figure out why my page wasnt generating.  =( Gotchya #2 The date prepended in the post file name (yyyy-mm-dd-you-post-name) does not matter at all.  In fact, the title also does not matter.  The values in the "front matter" portion of the posts is what is used to determine if a post will be generated for the site.

entry.title: How will I write content?
entry.content: One of the challenges of getting started with jekyll is figuring out how to write content for your site.  After doing a very quick search of what's actually available and what other jekyllers are using, I have decided to move forward with using a visual editor like wordtohtml.net. Familiarity with HTML leaves me the option to use other tools or templates to write content more simply.  Also, if I find that I don't actually like using this pattern for writing content, the promise from jekyll is that it is easy to change.  I have my fingers crossed.
